In rendering to our Patrons the compli-
nents of the season, we embrace the op'
pcrtunity to offer our cordial and unfeigned
thanks for the very liberal encouragement
we have received the past year. We fiat
ter ourselves that the -Ne7v Year will
prove as propitious as the old; and that we
may not be disappointed in our expectations,
we pledge our time, industry, and best en-
deavours, to render the WILMINGToNIAN
worthy the liberal patronage with which it
is honoured. Those who have been punctual
IN their payments for the paper, have our
warmest thanks.-To those who have not,
We wish better memories and a correct
sense Of justice. Our wish however, to all is,
MAY each be blest with all that Heaven can


send,


Long health. long life, long pleasure and a


friend"


As il has been usual for US to receive con-
siderable addition to our subscription list or
The commencement of the year, we have
printed an extra number Of copies, that the
paper can be furnished from the presen
date.

ALARM, of about IS acres, situated in MlcreeE
Hundred, Newcastle county, Del, about three

ton, of which about ten acres are wood land, and
the residue arabic, we'll set with orchard grass
and clover. The Buildings are, good stone
dwelling house, "a by "a feet, two stories high,


With three rooms on the first floor, and four on
the second, with good cellar under the whole
"a frame Harm, ceared under, Sc by SO feet
a Stone Joiner's shop, and Corncrib, % by II


feet, and stone smoke-house, all of which are
nearly new and in good order. The quality OF


the land is well adapted for farming or grazing
and has been we'll lined; it is in good ne,gh-
bourhood, near several places ofpub'c worship,


is in a good neighbourhood for Mills, and within


two t, % miles off good Limestone quarry hers is
likewise, a yoang thrifty Apple. Orchard, and


Peach Orchard. and the land is well waterea red


with good springs For ir'Hsf Wpnrton p0tp''s or m on

In the Senate. on Thursday, the resolution
submitted by Mr. johnson of Kentucky, for an
inquiry into the expcdiency of changing the ~
,lical system of the q. States, so AS to make the
Execution Laws of the several states, tor the
time being, the rule to govern the courts OF the
United States in the several states, was taken up
and agreed to. The Senate then took up the
Bankrupt Bill, and agreed to the amendments re-
ported by the committee, which were explained
by Mr. TIayne and Mr.. Bcrrien.


In the House of Representatives. Mr.. Reed IN
troduced a resolution, referring it TO the naval
committee, to consider the expectancy OF estab-
fishing q communication across the lsthmus OF
Panama.


Ia the Senate on Tuesday, Mr.. Macon OF
North Carolina was elected President pro
tempore, on the first baiot, and took the char
A bill providing for reports OF decisions IN
the supreme court of the u. States, was re-
ported from the committee on the Judiciary.
The consideration of the Bankrupt bill was
resumed. The bill was further amended &
ordered to be reprinted, with all the accom-
panying amendments.


In the House of Representatives Mr. " eb-
ster reported bill to establish a uniform
system of Bankruptcy, which he gave notice
of his intention to call up on "Wednesday the
/ 18th of January. Mr.. Livingston offered a
Resolution appfoPriatlhS oo'o"o uo'i''' io'
the relief of the Greeks; which was laid on
the table and ordered to be printed. Mr.
Hamilton offered resolution on the sub
ject of compensation to such as had suffered
under the alien and sedition laws. which ht
gave notice of his intention to call up OF
Monday the 18th of January. The bill t
provide for the importation OF brandy II
casks of not less capacity than fifteen gallon


was, after some discussion, ordered to o'
engrossed in the form in which it was re
ported by the Committee on Commerce, ant
read third time to day.
Yours, &c.
CONGRESS-.

Thomas Je6erson.--In the House OF Del
egates of South Carolina, OH the 18th inst,
a Preamble and Resolutions from the Sen
ate, were read by the Speaker, appropriat-
ing the sum of ten thousand dollars OF SIX
per cent stock, rcdcemable in the year
1850, to the legal Representatives, for the
benefit of the heirs of THOMAS JEFFER-
SON. On the motion being put they pass
ed unanimously. They had passed the Sen
ate with nearly the same unanimity.


The following letter details the circum-
stances which attended the passage of the
bill through the legislature


Extract of a letter from Columbia, s. c.,


Dec. 81, 1926.


"I wrote YOU by the last mail of the sue
cess of the appropriation of $1,000 to Mrs.
Randolph in our Senate, and ventured to
predict that it would succeed in the House.
It has done so But the next day, (yester-
dav.0 when the question occurred on the
appropriation bill, there was an unexpected
and serious opposition to it. Seven gentle
men. the number required by the rules OF
the House, rose to demand the ayes and
noes. Upon this the matter was discussed ;
and then the Speaker asked, will seven gen
tlemen rise tor the ayes and noes! -Four
got up-then another. Cries OF shame
Shame! we're heard in the hall, and the ut
most excitement manifested. Another one
rose-and tho most breathless anxiety pre-
vailed. When the Speaker announced
"Tbere are six up" several voices cxclaim-
ed awe will surrender our pay bills" The
Sneaker, with manifest exultation, said 'the
ovcs and noes are not demanded--.here are

.but six up." Upon the instant, there was
a shout re-echoed through the House
bursting from the warm hearts of those no.
bic South Carolinians, as on the news OF
great victory. Mutual congratulations were
exchanged, and they grasped each others
hands, and called out across the Hall, in the
forgetfulness of the gravity of their station.
w .ile several of my friends were shaking
hands with me in the Lobby, the door keep
er stepped up to us and said, I" am glad
they have passed this law for if they had
rejected it would not have been door keep
er for them an hour longer" The sum of
$40 900 was fixed upon after much delibe.
ration. 1t is a round sum. More might have
been obJectionable-less would have been
mean. There was a proposition in CONVEX
sation, to buy NJ onticelo and give it to her;
but it was thought best to leave this for Vir-
ginia."


Ne,U Muention.-We have seen gun with five
barrels, made or put together in the form of All


sosceles triangle, having one lock on the per-
cussion principle; all the barrels are dischared at
once. The gun is placed in tr angular box of
wood SO constructed as to float on the level of
the water with the tide Connected with the
lock isl cord by which this gun can be fired at
a distance of 300 yards. The inventors are two
ingenious young mechanics, brothers, of the
name of Ferguson. The gun is intended to be
used in the Canvass Back war on the Chesa-
peake bay. We shall hear how it succeeds in a
few days.--N Y .9duocate.


On Monday last, according to established u.s.
age on NewYear's day, the Presidents house
was open for the reception of visitors, when,
Notwithstanding the day was extremely cold,
the President received the congratulations of a
larger number than it is believed was ever assem-
bled any similar, or other occasion, in the Ex-
ccutive mansion: all the rooms, including the
great eastern room, as well as the large Hall,
were crowded to excess, for several hours, al
| though there was a constant change of the COM
pany, occasioned by the retiring some, and the
entrance of others. The foreign ministers gen.
orally were present, with the members of their
respective legations; all the heads of Depart


ments, the members of both Houses ofCongress,
the principal and other officers of the govern
mcnt, civil military, and naval, besides an i'm


mense number ofstrangcrs, amounting to sever


al thousands. The annual interchange of salu-


tations between the President of the United


States and the citizens, on the commencement


of the year, gives to the day the peculiar charac


ter of a Republican festival; the observance u
which, we trust, will never be discontinued.

The bill to prevent horse-racing in New
Jersey. has been dismissed BY the legislature
of that state by majority of four


A man named Carol, belonging to Mar
blchead. in prison at Salem, Mass. for abus-
ing his family and neighbors, lately attempt.
ed to murder his wife who had paid him
visit in prison. She was wounded badly.


The law Of Georgia, by which the State
was divided into districts for the election of
members of Congress, has been repealed.


The number OF Free Scools in South Car
olina, is about 746, in which 9O61 children
are instructed. Their annual expense to the
State is 81 ,643 dollars.


An attempt is making in Baltimore to form
small Library of moral and religious books
for the perusal of the prisoners in the Jail of
that city.


Mr.. Herwick, of New York, has obtain
ed patent for inventing new mode of
making boys clothes, which is said to unite
neatness with comfort. being plant to the
attitudes of boy, and thus benefting his
health and growth.

DUNG the last summer. with the Chippewa
nation OF Indians, has occupied the attention
OF the Senate, in its executive sittings, for
several days. The ratification of the Trea-
| ty is said to involve constitutional difficult
ty.

lie Roy, New York, who had been insan

The highest wages are offered to mechan

nducement is held out to seamen to ship

ceived him on his arrival in the city with th

September %.


By the mail arrived this morning from the in
terror we have accounts from Bolivia, which, it
true, arc certainly of most transcendent import
ance-but which, from their very extraordinary
character. would seem hardly entitled to credit
Letters, it appears to-day received, state that
General Sucrc, President of that Republic, has
proposed to Congress the adoption of one OFT wo
measures: that of the immediate declaration OF
war against the Argentine Provinces, or should
ths step be considered too violent that OF cut
ting off all intercourse between the two Repub-
lies; and, it is added, as preparatory to such
strange proceedings, lie has occupied Terija,
heretofore under the Provincial jurisdiction OF
Sata 1t is said that the motive of all this is that
of forcing this Government to recognition OF
the independence of Bolivia. That new Re-
public having been erected by union Of several
Provinces which formerly belonged to the con-
fcderacy of the U. P. of La Plata' and the thus
establishing an independent Government being
understood to have been contrary to the wishes
of a large portion of its inhabitants, who were
desirous Of again uniting themselves to the Ar.
pentine family; the Government of the latter,
from motives which may clearly appear, has de-
laycd to acknowledge them an independent Ma
ton of which, according to these accounts, the!
are about to manifest their sentlmennt.
give you this report hastily, as | have just re
ccived it, at moment when it has produced con
siderable excitement in the city; but, indeed, i
bears upon the face of il, not only the feature o
mprobabty, but that ofcxtrcme righteousness
, Ruinor further states that DR.. Serrano arrive,
some months ago in this city AS Minister from 80
, iva, but that the Government refused to receive
r him, and he has since returned to his country
But confess that, before to-day, had not hear'
of the Bolivian Mission. nor Of the name of DR.
Serrano.

The Secretary IF IPur to Gor. Iroup.


DEPARTMENT OF WAR, 9th Nov 1926.


Cir. A long and distressing illness has prevent
cd me from replying to your letter OF the oth
~. Since my partial recovery, have submit
,nd It to the President, by whom am instruct
od IN saw, that you appear TO labor under most
sa,;o,s mistake in supposing that the last treaty
,,;,b the Creeks has effected in any manner the
boundary of Georgia. There is not title in
tbc treaty that has the most distant ailuslon to
that object, nor for one moment would discus
.;op have been admitted thereon, as it lies entire
" ott ofthe competency of the General Govern
mcnt. In anxiously wishing to embrace all their
land within the limits of Georgia, every effort
was male to indnce them to agree to a clause to
that effect, in so MANY words. They promptly
refused, on the ground of their ignorance of the
direction of that line Had the dividing line be-
tween Georgia and Alabama been established, !
think il highly probable that we should have
succeeded in obtaining their REIMBURSEMENT; the
more especially as perceive that, even by the
sine run by the Georgia Commissioners, to which
i i understood unofii cially the Alabama Com
missioners dsscnted, there is less than 200, 900
acres of Indian Lands. 1t is a matter of regret
that any difficulty should have occurred between
Georgia and Alabama, in fixing their dividing
line. as the President had designed, the moment
the dividing line had been established. tqupen
fresh negotiations with the Greeks for the Pur-
nose fprocuring any fragment of land such line
might have left of theirs within the limits of
Georgia. Without entering at all into the ,ner-
its of the controversy between Georgia and Ala
bama YOUR cxcellcncy must at once perceive
that the original difficulty 90 an entire cession
continues to impede our course, and the first in
stant that it shall be removed will be the one
which the Executive will embrace to carry into
effect, by fresh negotiations, if practicable the
entire cession.


have the honor TO be, sir, your obedicnt SER
want. JAMES BARBOUR
His Excellcncy, GEo. NJ. 1nour,


Governor OF Georgia.

The Worcester (Mass.) Spy states that
several bales OF cotton have been raised
the past season in the garden of Daniel Wal
do, OF that town, the wool Of which is per-
fectly ripe and of good staple.


Committees have been appointed in all the
wards of Philadelphia, to solicit contribu-
tions for the relief of the suffering women
and children, and the helpless old men of
Greece.

Admiral Brown left this city on 18th August,
with an escort of 20 persons, and crossed the
country to Correntes. He remained several
days at n farm house at that place, and on the
Sth instant, the Chilian fleet, g frigates and
corvette, purchased from the Chilian govern
meht, by that of Buenos Ayres) appeared oil the
Cape, and, it is sad he embarked the same day
on board the frigate "Buenos Ayrts" and took
command. Ere this, he is no doubt, securing the !
Brazilian Coast, and may astonish the "gilt-gn-
ger bread Emperor by his sudden appearance
off RIO de Janeiro. Perhaps it may reasonably
be expected that while His Majesty is maintain
ing his whole naval force in this river, for the
purpose of eh'ecting dilated blockade of call
the Argentine ports" our intrepid Admiral may
blockade, in turn, that of the Capital of the En-
pirc


| We have intelligence that Admiral Guedez
has left Montevideo with five heavy vessels on
cruise without the Capcs, and was seen when
days out, steering nolthwardly. This force IL
superior to Admiral Browns But, with us. dis
parity of force is no longer admitted as basis
of speculation-we have now ceased to consider
the physical superiority of the Brazans fit
data whence to set out with our calculations as to
the probable result of our naval conflicts. We
apprehend nothing for the safety of Brown, in
the case of collision Of the hostile heet--rather


we do not hesitate to believe that, in such an e.


vent, scarcely will he fail to give good account


of Admiral Guedez and his five fiigates.


Tn the meantime, General Alvear late Sccrc-


tary of War, having crossed the river from this


city in the schooner tsSarandi," within sight of


the blockading squadron, has taken command in


person of the army in the Banda Orental and


secret, though active preparations are now maxi


ing for opening the campaign with a sudden in


vasion of the Brazilian territory: and to this the
present moment is rendered peculiarly propi-


tous by the fame of revolution which is now


kndng throughout the Empire Admiral Brown
: was provided with some thousands of printed


hsnd-bills, proclamations, &c. to be judiciously


attributed along the coast.


o At the time Of General Alvear's arrival at Head
0 Quarter, considerable dscord from unaccountable
0 motives, existed in the camp, which soon broke
y out into open rebellion. The insurgents, 700
a in number, Orientalists, and headed by Bcrnabe
Q Rivera, (brother to the celebrated Frutos Rivera
0 who passed over from the Brazilians, al the com
mencement of the war, with 600 men, and who


prior to that, had deserted the patriot standard,
i. withdrew from the main body and encampcd a
> bout nine miles distant. A detachment march


ed against them under the personal command o


Avear and Lavalleja. Immediately, the scditou'
troops, forsaking their leader, reunited them


selves with the army, and I,crnabe Rivera wa
: taken prisoner. 1t was at this moment that
l. correspondence was intercepted by General Al
}" wear, which went to expose, at the same time
ID the low intrigues of the Brazilian Emperor anc
1T his satellites, and meditated treason (for thu
t. THIRD rrME) on the part of Frutos and Bernsb
III Rivera; to the former of whom General Leco
,e was ordered by his Imperial Majesty to pay 25,
S, 900 dollars, and proportonatc sum to each off
u Ger that should ompany him. This CORES
N pondence was Immediately transmitted by 81
il year to the Government.


al During these events, Frutos Rivera was on
,r visit to this city and having already shown him
IT. self by his treacherous conduct aernateyto bot
ct parties, unworthy the confidence of ethcr,t Gt
is. vernment was unwilling he should return to til
an Banda Oriental, where his popularity and inhl


cnce were so considerable; and had for som
time been amusing him, now with the offer {


the office of Inspector General of this c,ty-no
n with that of the Governorship Of the newl
on formed Province, contiguous to the capital: bI
We OH the receipt of the correspondence above a
he uded to, it proceeded, forthwith, to take sue
mt measures as the nature and the importance


disclosure required. Unfortunately, howcve


for the cause of Justice and the country, this tt


extraordinary and dangerous man who had hr
10 self, and at the same moment, been apprised
'o- all which had transpired, effected his escape
lot the very night that the intelligence was receives
ch On the following morning an edict of the Go
m; ernment was published, in official form, in 8
we the papers of the city, citing Rivera to appea
me within the brief term of "a hours, to answer
he charges of high treason. This was a consider
ice BILE shock to the public mnd-it was the first
we tmation our citizens had received of his conteI
ID plated crime against the State. Not partcip;


ing in the dstrusts Of the Government, they

.po;,t mn Poini."--A villain has escaped the
c,ote Prison in New-York, by one of the incest
Ss,;uctons in law immaginable. He snatched
! watch from Mr.. Boggs in one Instant ana
Knocked him down in the next--this reduced the
crime to petit larceny; whereas if he had knock
cd the man down the instant before he seized the
watch, it would have been highway robbery rac-
corling to law" Truly "the odds IS the diner
ence."

The Baltimore American says, the Bank
rupt Bill was taken up in the Senate of the
United States, on Thursday, and the a
mendments proposed by the committee con-
sidered The commercial community has
long desired the passage of general bank
rupt law, and we trust that during the pres
ent Session the measure will receive the
sanction of Congress.


Our latest advices from Buenos Ayres, are
to the 30th Sept. inclusive. Our Correspon-
dent corroborates the statement heretofore
received of Admiral Brown having embark
ed on board the "Buenos Mres," one of the
Chian frigatcs destined for the La Plata.
On the goth, a Brazilian schooner carrying
9 guns and sc men arrived at Buenos hyres,
a prize to the Profeta Bandarra, which
vessel captured her off Maldonado. North
American -four was selling on the 30th at
S3i; Virginia Tobacco, per qu'ntal, S35
Cow Hides, pesada, 6; Ok. 8; Meats. 5l14
Horse, ll3; Calf, Z; Horns pr. m 70. Span
ish dollars lis per cent premium.

full articles.headline:
Txzy; WzxryTryg GTonJEAN,

DELAWARE ADVERTISER.



Thursday, Jan'ry. a, 1927.
full articles.article:
In rendering to our Patrons the compli-
nents of the season, we embrace the op'
pcrtunity to offer our cordial and unfeigned
thanks for the very liberal encouragement
we have received the past year. We fiat
ter ourselves that the -Ne7v Year will
prove as propitious as the old; and that we
may not be disappointed in our expectations,
we pledge our time, industry, and best en-
deavours, to render the WILMINGToNIAN
worthy the liberal patronage with which it
is honoured. Those who have been punctual
IN their payments for the paper, have our
warmest thanks.-To those who have not,
We wish better memories and a correct
sense Of justice. Our wish however, to all is,
MAY each be blest with all that Heaven can


send,


Long health. long life, long pleasure and a


friend"


As il has been usual for US to receive con-
siderable addition to our subscription list or
The commencement of the year, we have
printed an extra number Of copies, that the
paper can be furnished from the presen
date.

full articles.headline: FOR SALE,
full articles.article:
ALARM, of about IS acres, situated in MlcreeE
Hundred, Newcastle county, Del, about three
miles from Staunton, and eight from Whining,
ton, of which about ten acres are wood land, and
the residue arabic, we'll set with orchard grass
and clover. The Buildings are, good stone
dwelling house, "a by "a feet, two stories high,


With three rooms on the first floor, and four on
the second, with good cellar under the whole
"a frame Harm, ceared under, Sc by SO feet
a Stone Joiner's shop, and Corncrib, % by II


feet, and stone smoke-house, all of which are
nearly new and in good order. The quality OF


the land is well adapted for farming or grazing
and has been we'll lined; it is in good ne,gh-
bourhood, near several places ofpub'c worship,


is in a good neighbourhood for Mills, and within


two t, % miles off good Limestone quarry hers is
likewise, a yoang thrifty Apple. Orchard, and


Peach Orchard. and the land is well waterea red


with good springs For ir'Hsf Wpnrton p0tp''s or m on
Iu''c :. sf JOHN FERRIS.
| 10Th Mo. 20, 1870. - 80

full articles.headline:
Yours, &c.

CONGRESS-.
full articles.article:
In the Senate. on Thursday, the resolution
submitted by Mr. johnson of Kentucky, for an
inquiry into the expcdiency of changing the ~
,lical system of the q. States, so AS to make the
Execution Laws of the several states, tor the
time being, the rule to govern the courts OF the
United States in the several states, was taken up
and agreed to. The Senate then took up the
Bankrupt Bill, and agreed to the amendments re-
ported by the committee, which were explained
by Mr. TIayne and Mr.. Bcrrien.


In the House of Representatives. Mr.. Reed IN
troduced a resolution, referring it TO the naval
committee, to consider the expectancy OF estab-
fishing q communication across the lsthmus OF
Panama.


Ia the Senate on Tuesday, Mr.. Macon OF
North Carolina was elected President pro
tempore, on the first baiot, and took the char
A bill providing for reports OF decisions IN
the supreme court of the u. States, was re-
ported from the committee on the Judiciary.
The consideration of the Bankrupt bill was
resumed. The bill was further amended &
ordered to be reprinted, with all the accom-
panying amendments.


In the House of Representatives Mr. " eb-
ster reported bill to establish a uniform
system of Bankruptcy, which he gave notice
of his intention to call up on "Wednesday the
/ 18th of January. Mr.. Livingston offered a
Resolution appfoPriatlhS oo'o"o uo'i''' io'
the relief of the Greeks; which was laid on
the table and ordered to be printed. Mr.
Hamilton offered resolution on the sub
ject of compensation to such as had suffered
under the alien and sedition laws. which ht
gave notice of his intention to call up OF
Monday the 18th of January. The bill t
provide for the importation OF brandy II
casks of not less capacity than fifteen gallon


was, after some discussion, ordered to o'
engrossed in the form in which it was re
ported by the Committee on Commerce, ant
read third time to day.

Thomas Je6erson.--In the House OF Del
egates of South Carolina, OH the 18th inst,
a Preamble and Resolutions from the Sen
ate, were read by the Speaker, appropriat-
ing the sum of ten thousand dollars OF SIX
per cent stock, rcdcemable in the year
1850, to the legal Representatives, for the
benefit of the heirs of THOMAS JEFFER-
SON. On the motion being put they pass
ed unanimously. They had passed the Sen
ate with nearly the same unanimity.


The following letter details the circum-
stances which attended the passage of the
bill through the legislature


Extract of a letter from Columbia, s. c.,


Dec. 81, 1926.


"I wrote YOU by the last mail of the sue
cess of the appropriation of $1,000 to Mrs.
Randolph in our Senate, and ventured to
predict that it would succeed in the House.
It has done so But the next day, (yester-
dav.0 when the question occurred on the
appropriation bill, there was an unexpected
and serious opposition to it. Seven gentle
men. the number required by the rules OF
the House, rose to demand the ayes and
noes. Upon this the matter was discussed ;
and then the Speaker asked, will seven gen
tlemen rise tor the ayes and noes! -Four
got up-then another. Cries OF shame
Shame! we're heard in the hall, and the ut
most excitement manifested. Another one
rose-and tho most breathless anxiety pre-
vailed. When the Speaker announced
"Tbere are six up" several voices cxclaim-
ed awe will surrender our pay bills" The
Sneaker, with manifest exultation, said 'the
ovcs and noes are not demanded--.here are

.but six up." Upon the instant, there was
a shout re-echoed through the House
bursting from the warm hearts of those no.
bic South Carolinians, as on the news OF
great victory. Mutual congratulations were
exchanged, and they grasped each others
hands, and called out across the Hall, in the
forgetfulness of the gravity of their station.
w .ile several of my friends were shaking
hands with me in the Lobby, the door keep
er stepped up to us and said, I" am glad
they have passed this law for if they had
rejected it would not have been door keep
er for them an hour longer" The sum of
$40 900 was fixed upon after much delibe.
ration. 1t is a round sum. More might have
been obJectionable-less would have been
mean. There was a proposition in CONVEX
sation, to buy NJ onticelo and give it to her;
but it was thought best to leave this for Vir-
ginia."


Ne,U Muention.-We have seen gun with five
barrels, made or put together in the form of All


sosceles triangle, having one lock on the per-
cussion principle; all the barrels are dischared at
once. The gun is placed in tr angular box of
wood SO constructed as to float on the level of
the water with the tide Connected with the
lock isl cord by which this gun can be fired at
a distance of 300 yards. The inventors are two
ingenious young mechanics, brothers, of the
name of Ferguson. The gun is intended to be
used in the Canvass Back war on the Chesa-
peake bay. We shall hear how it succeeds in a
few days.--N Y .9duocate.


On Monday last, according to established u.s.
age on NewYear's day, the Presidents house
was open for the reception of visitors, when,
Notwithstanding the day was extremely cold,
the President received the congratulations of a
larger number than it is believed was ever assem-
bled any similar, or other occasion, in the Ex-
ccutive mansion: all the rooms, including the
great eastern room, as well as the large Hall,
were crowded to excess, for several hours, al
| though there was a constant change of the COM
pany, occasioned by the retiring some, and the
entrance of others. The foreign ministers gen.
orally were present, with the members of their
respective legations; all the heads of Depart


ments, the members of both Houses ofCongress,
the principal and other officers of the govern
mcnt, civil military, and naval, besides an i'm


mense number ofstrangcrs, amounting to sever


al thousands. The annual interchange of salu-


tations between the President of the United


States and the citizens, on the commencement


of the year, gives to the day the peculiar charac


ter of a Republican festival; the observance u
which, we trust, will never be discontinued.

full articles.headline: GLEANINGS.
full articles.article:
The bill to prevent horse-racing in New
Jersey. has been dismissed BY the legislature
of that state by majority of four


A man named Carol, belonging to Mar
blchead. in prison at Salem, Mass. for abus-
ing his family and neighbors, lately attempt.
ed to murder his wife who had paid him
visit in prison. She was wounded badly.


The law Of Georgia, by which the State
was divided into districts for the election of
members of Congress, has been repealed.


The number OF Free Scools in South Car
olina, is about 746, in which 9O61 children
are instructed. Their annual expense to the
State is 81 ,643 dollars.


An attempt is making in Baltimore to form
small Library of moral and religious books
for the perusal of the prisoners in the Jail of
that city.


Mr.. Herwick, of New York, has obtain
ed patent for inventing new mode of
making boys clothes, which is said to unite
neatness with comfort. being plant to the
attitudes of boy, and thus benefting his
health and growth.


In 1875, there were imported from
the British West Indies Sl,45I,55 in gold
and silver coin-trom the North American
Colonies S5l4.7 .739-the duties per ann. on
importations from the b. w. Indies e52,6S5
dollars.


The Treaty made by Governor Cass,
DUNG the last summer. with the Chippewa
nation OF Indians, has occupied the attention
OF the Senate, in its executive sittings, for
several days. The ratification of the Trea-
| ty is said to involve constitutional difficult
ty.


| 1t is suggested by some Journal that all
class-i of persons feeling an interest in tue
bankrupt law should take measures to pre-
sent memorials to congress on their particu
lar views


a letter from Turks Island, of the 4t
instant states-''A fine American brig ha,
Just come in to load with salt and is ordered
off,


A man named Daniel House has been ar
rested for cutting letters of their pecuniar,
contents in some Massachusetts post-otfice
This House was very properly removed tt
another house-of correction. The paper
say our "sccond Daniel will come to judg


ment."


Isaac Anthony, residing In the town O


lie Roy, New York, who had been insan


for a number of years, lately broke loos
: from his chains, and killed his aged mother
, Reuben Rankin who was to have been ex
ecuted in Kentucky, on the 6th ult. for tn
murder of John Blake of Ohio, took opiur


pills IN such quantities as to Kill him befor
the hour of execution.
r A city paper cautions the public to be o
: their guard against receiving counterfe
cents, which are fabricated of cast iror


and must have cost the ingenious artist b
whom they were made, as much as the col
they were intended to represent.


The duties arising on imports into the di:
trict of NewYork for the quarter endin
Sept. 30th, exceed S3.o00,000.
1t is curious fact that the int!uenz


which prevailed hnre so generally, we ma


say universally, IN this country, last wnts
= and spring, was also felt at Calcutta and


the Sandwich Islands.

full articles.headline: THE NAVY OF MEXICO.
full articles.article:
We learn from Vera Cruz, that the ma
v,l commanders, comodore Porter, was max
ing the greatest exertions to place the naval
force of the country on a respectable footing.
The highest wages are offered to mechan
les and laborers in the ship yards. and every
nducement is held out to seamen to ship
The government appears to have gwen the
commodore extensive powers, and placed at
his disposal liberal means. Already the ma
val force OF that country presents respect
able appearance upon paper. lhe follow
ing are the vessels which compose it, viz !;


In actual serpice.-Congrcss "a guns-Li-
bertad 40-Guerrero 22--Constantia 20
Victoria lS--Bravo 16-Schooners Herman,
Luciano, i lascatica, Arizaba, Papaloapar,
Tampico, Felix.


In ordinary, ,--Iguala, Anahuac, Ricardo,
Chaico. and Tcscuco.


BuRding-One corvette, % guns.


Total. Nineteen sail.


The principal naval establishments arc
Vera Cruz, .Avarado and ST. Bias.


The pay of the officers is as follows:


Captaiu de Navio, with the rank of Briga.
dier General, per annum, $4,000
Captain de Fragata, 360(
First Lieutenant in command, 2l6(
Second do 144t
Niidshipmcn of first Class, 44-


Do second Class 20
First Boatswain, 72'
Second do 4S
Captains of guns, per month 2
Seamen,

near the Friend Meeting House, where he wiii

Bro,sn soap, Of the best quality.

Wilmington, Nov. Is, 1870

ceived him on his arrival in the city with th
greatest cordiality, gave him public dinners, re-
quired his attendance at their balls and parties,
and in grateful feeling for the signal service he
had rendered the cause, in his desertion from the
Brazilian ranks, seemed willing to forget all his
former errors, and however much they might adj
mire the treason that they had to detest, or, at
least, that they ought ever to dstrust the traitor.


1t is said that Rivera was seen, six days after
he left this city, with Is well armed men, on the
road from Sta Fe, which, from the first estab-
lshment of the present permanent Executive,
has been the seat of discomfort and revolution,
only kept down by the prase-worthy exertions
and activity, of General La Madrid.


September %.


By the mail arrived this morning from the in
terror we have accounts from Bolivia, which, it
true, arc certainly of most transcendent import
ance-but which, from their very extraordinary
character. would seem hardly entitled to credit
Letters, it appears to-day received, state that
General Sucrc, President of that Republic, has
proposed to Congress the adoption of one OFT wo
measures: that of the immediate declaration OF
war against the Argentine Provinces, or should
ths step be considered too violent that OF cut
ting off all intercourse between the two Repub-
lies; and, it is added, as preparatory to such
strange proceedings, lie has occupied Terija,
heretofore under the Provincial jurisdiction OF
Sata 1t is said that the motive of all this is that
of forcing this Government to recognition OF
the independence of Bolivia. That new Re-
public having been erected by union Of several
Provinces which formerly belonged to the con-
fcderacy of the U. P. of La Plata' and the thus
establishing an independent Government being
understood to have been contrary to the wishes
of a large portion of its inhabitants, who were
desirous Of again uniting themselves to the Ar.
pentine family; the Government of the latter,
from motives which may clearly appear, has de-
laycd to acknowledge them an independent Ma
ton of which, according to these accounts, the!
are about to manifest their sentlmennt.
give you this report hastily, as | have just re
ccived it, at moment when it has produced con
siderable excitement in the city; but, indeed, i
bears upon the face of il, not only the feature o
mprobabty, but that ofcxtrcme righteousness
, Ruinor further states that DR.. Serrano arrive,
some months ago in this city AS Minister from 80
, iva, but that the Government refused to receive
r him, and he has since returned to his country
But confess that, before to-day, had not hear'
of the Bolivian Mission. nor Of the name of DR.
Serrano.


Yours, &c.

full articles.headline: OFFICIAL PAPER.
full articles.article:
The Secretary IF IPur to Gor. Iroup.


DEPARTMENT OF WAR, 9th Nov 1926.


Cir. A long and distressing illness has prevent
cd me from replying to your letter OF the oth
~. Since my partial recovery, have submit
,nd It to the President, by whom am instruct
od IN saw, that you appear TO labor under most
sa,;o,s mistake in supposing that the last treaty
,,;,b the Creeks has effected in any manner the
boundary of Georgia. There is not title in
tbc treaty that has the most distant ailuslon to
that object, nor for one moment would discus
.;op have been admitted thereon, as it lies entire
" ott ofthe competency of the General Govern
mcnt. In anxiously wishing to embrace all their
land within the limits of Georgia, every effort
was male to indnce them to agree to a clause to
that effect, in so MANY words. They promptly
refused, on the ground of their ignorance of the
direction of that line Had the dividing line be-
tween Georgia and Alabama been established, !
think il highly probable that we should have
succeeded in obtaining their REIMBURSEMENT; the
more especially as perceive that, even by the
sine run by the Georgia Commissioners, to which
i i understood unofii cially the Alabama Com
missioners dsscnted, there is less than 200, 900
acres of Indian Lands. 1t is a matter of regret
that any difficulty should have occurred between
Georgia and Alabama, in fixing their dividing
line. as the President had designed, the moment
the dividing line had been established. tqupen
fresh negotiations with the Greeks for the Pur-
nose fprocuring any fragment of land such line
might have left of theirs within the limits of
Georgia. Without entering at all into the ,ner-
its of the controversy between Georgia and Ala
bama YOUR cxcellcncy must at once perceive
that the original difficulty 90 an entire cession
continues to impede our course, and the first in
stant that it shall be removed will be the one
which the Executive will embrace to carry into
effect, by fresh negotiations, if practicable the
entire cession.


have the honor TO be, sir, your obedicnt SER
want. JAMES BARBOUR
His Excellcncy, GEo. NJ. 1nour,


Governor OF Georgia.

full articles.headline: Delaware State Lottery,
full articles.article:
SIXTH CLASS,
For the benefit of Newark College, Middletown
Academy, and Emmanuel Church.
60 No. Lottery.-9 dra,on Ballots.
To be drawn at Del, on the 14th day


Of March, 1927.

The Worcester (Mass.) Spy states that
several bales OF cotton have been raised
the past season in the garden of Daniel Wal
do, OF that town, the wool Of which is per-
fectly ripe and of good staple.


Committees have been appointed in all the
wards of Philadelphia, to solicit contribu-
tions for the relief of the suffering women
and children, and the helpless old men of
Greece.

full articles.headline:
Ertract of a letter to the Editor Of the UIimiag'


.0niun, dafed
full articles.article:
Admiral Brown left this city on 18th August,
with an escort of 20 persons, and crossed the
country to Correntes. He remained several
days at n farm house at that place, and on the
Sth instant, the Chilian fleet, g frigates and
corvette, purchased from the Chilian govern
meht, by that of Buenos Ayres) appeared oil the
Cape, and, it is sad he embarked the same day
on board the frigate "Buenos Ayrts" and took
command. Ere this, he is no doubt, securing the !
Brazilian Coast, and may astonish the "gilt-gn-
ger bread Emperor by his sudden appearance
off RIO de Janeiro. Perhaps it may reasonably
be expected that while His Majesty is maintain
ing his whole naval force in this river, for the
purpose of eh'ecting dilated blockade of call
the Argentine ports" our intrepid Admiral may
blockade, in turn, that of the Capital of the En-
pirc


| We have intelligence that Admiral Guedez
has left Montevideo with five heavy vessels on
cruise without the Capcs, and was seen when
days out, steering nolthwardly. This force IL
superior to Admiral Browns But, with us. dis
parity of force is no longer admitted as basis
of speculation-we have now ceased to consider
the physical superiority of the Brazans fit
data whence to set out with our calculations as to
the probable result of our naval conflicts. We
apprehend nothing for the safety of Brown, in
the case of collision Of the hostile heet--rather


we do not hesitate to believe that, in such an e.


vent, scarcely will he fail to give good account


of Admiral Guedez and his five fiigates.


Tn the meantime, General Alvear late Sccrc-


tary of War, having crossed the river from this


city in the schooner tsSarandi," within sight of


the blockading squadron, has taken command in


person of the army in the Banda Orental and


secret, though active preparations are now maxi


ing for opening the campaign with a sudden in


vasion of the Brazilian territory: and to this the
present moment is rendered peculiarly propi-


tous by the fame of revolution which is now


kndng throughout the Empire Admiral Brown
: was provided with some thousands of printed


hsnd-bills, proclamations, &c. to be judiciously


attributed along the coast.


o At the time Of General Alvear's arrival at Head
0 Quarter, considerable dscord from unaccountable
0 motives, existed in the camp, which soon broke
y out into open rebellion. The insurgents, 700
a in number, Orientalists, and headed by Bcrnabe
Q Rivera, (brother to the celebrated Frutos Rivera
0 who passed over from the Brazilians, al the com
mencement of the war, with 600 men, and who


prior to that, had deserted the patriot standard,
i. withdrew from the main body and encampcd a
> bout nine miles distant. A detachment march


ed against them under the personal command o


Avear and Lavalleja. Immediately, the scditou'
troops, forsaking their leader, reunited them


selves with the army, and I,crnabe Rivera wa
: taken prisoner. 1t was at this moment that
l. correspondence was intercepted by General Al
}" wear, which went to expose, at the same time
ID the low intrigues of the Brazilian Emperor anc
1T his satellites, and meditated treason (for thu
t. THIRD rrME) on the part of Frutos and Bernsb
III Rivera; to the former of whom General Leco
,e was ordered by his Imperial Majesty to pay 25,
S, 900 dollars, and proportonatc sum to each off
u Ger that should ompany him. This CORES
N pondence was Immediately transmitted by 81
il year to the Government.


al During these events, Frutos Rivera was on
,r visit to this city and having already shown him
IT. self by his treacherous conduct aernateyto bot
ct parties, unworthy the confidence of ethcr,t Gt
is. vernment was unwilling he should return to til
an Banda Oriental, where his popularity and inhl


cnce were so considerable; and had for som
time been amusing him, now with the offer {


the office of Inspector General of this c,ty-no
n with that of the Governorship Of the newl
on formed Province, contiguous to the capital: bI
We OH the receipt of the correspondence above a
he uded to, it proceeded, forthwith, to take sue
mt measures as the nature and the importance


disclosure required. Unfortunately, howcve


for the cause of Justice and the country, this tt


extraordinary and dangerous man who had hr
10 self, and at the same moment, been apprised
'o- all which had transpired, effected his escape
lot the very night that the intelligence was receives
ch On the following morning an edict of the Go
m; ernment was published, in official form, in 8
we the papers of the city, citing Rivera to appea
me within the brief term of "a hours, to answer
he charges of high treason. This was a consider
ice BILE shock to the public mnd-it was the first
we tmation our citizens had received of his conteI
ID plated crime against the State. Not partcip;


ing in the dstrusts Of the Government, they

49,, hustle of crowded assembly. The sleep
;nr @ beauties were the admiration or the . room
wS never before, will venture to say, had they AZ
+ncted so much attention"


.po;,t mn Poini."--A villain has escaped the
c,ote Prison in New-York, by one of the incest
Ss,;uctons in law immaginable. He snatched
! watch from Mr.. Boggs in one Instant ana
Knocked him down in the next--this reduced the

The Baltimore American says, the Bank
rupt Bill was taken up in the Senate of the
United States, on Thursday, and the a
mendments proposed by the committee con-
sidered The commercial community has
long desired the passage of general bank
rupt law, and we trust that during the pres
ent Session the measure will receive the
sanction of Congress.


Our latest advices from Buenos Ayres, are
to the 30th Sept. inclusive. Our Correspon-
dent corroborates the statement heretofore
received of Admiral Brown having embark
ed on board the "Buenos Mres," one of the
Chian frigatcs destined for the La Plata.
On the goth, a Brazilian schooner carrying
9 guns and sc men arrived at Buenos hyres,
a prize to the Profeta Bandarra, which
vessel captured her off Maldonado. North
